bibl.title: Despatches from United States Consuls in Boma, 1888-1895
bibl.publisher: National Archives and Records Service General Services Administration

body.div1:
<pb facs="20170614_145206"
Honorable Josiah Quincy Assistant Secretary of State, Washington, D.C.
Sir: I have the honor to inform the Department of any arrival at this place. F ebuary 26th from Stanley Falls.
From Nov. 29th, the date of my last letter to the Department, I have travelled through most of the Mallela country lying between the Lomami + the Loua- laba, + have been down the Loualaba to Stanley Falls + Basoko returning ton Kassongo by the same road.
The Arab was being about finished Ruma Liya having been defeated and driven from the country, I shall have in a few days for the month of the LuKugu, 10 days ssold of here and follow the course of that river to the Tanganyika. This will
occupy
<pb facs="20170614_145213"
occupy at least five months. On arrival at Mpala, I shall go to the North end of the Lake, + from there to the South and Lake the Cloeason road to Nyassa, down the Lake to the there +on to Luietent on the East Coast. I hope to be on the Coast about September 1st + if the Department permits will take steamer from there to the Cape of Good Hope + on to Boma to settle my affairs + return to America on leave.
I have a force of sixty soldiers with me armed with th Albini rifle+ some hundred porters Jsap pose the total number of people in my caravan maybe put down . at 250.
I am in the best of the health I have had on letters or papers for ten months!
Respectfully R. Dorsey Mohew N.S. Commercial Agent
